results.title: Stirring the pool
results.creator_credit: Wayne Le Clos, Gil Brealey, Peter Weir, Commonwealth Public Service Board and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personnel or People”.
A new typist is asked to do a job for the manager instead of the senior typist, who is not present. Afterwards the senior typist voices her resentment, causing the new girl to feel unhappy. Another typist informs the new typist that the attitude of the senior typist is not new and has caused many resignations. What is the answer to internal warfare in the typing pool? Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Spotlight on Australian Ballet
results.creator_credit: Doc K Sternberg, Geoff Powell, Loch Townsend, A Anderson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A survey of the development of ballet in Australia. The contribution made by such enthusiasts as Edouard Borovansky, Helene Kirsova, Laurel Martyn, Dorothy Stevenson, and other Australian dancers in training and encouraging aspiring dancers, and the untiring efforts of the various corps des ballets, the majority of whom have had to fit in their clases and training, and in many cases, their actual performances, after normal working hours, are presented as the background to the status of ballet in Australia in 1948. Narrated by John Bushelle.

results.title: School's in, Soviet style
results.creator_credit: Martyn Down, Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Russian Education”.
Examines the present school system in the Soviet Union. Demonstrates the style of Soviet teaching which is fairly rigid and formal, with the emphasis on teacher dominated instruction and passive pupils, responding only when instructed to do so. A more flexible teaching style was introduced some years ago but was later abandoned. Photographer, Dean Semler; script, Roger Milliss; editor, Martyn Down; sound, George Hart, Howard Spry; commentator, Margaret Throsby.

results.title: Safety in the slaughterhouse
results.creator_credit: John Hoskins, John Bowen, Peter Johnson and Camfilm Productions
results.brief_description:
This 1979 film is directed at meat inspectors working in abbatoirs. The film contains footage of workers in abbatoirs and close-ups of inspectors working on carcasses. It includes interviews with three inspectors about the accidents they suffered during their work and a discussion at the pub between a group of meat inspectors on the problems they encounter in their work and the safety precautions they should note.

Produced by Camfilm Productions for the Department of Primary Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Safe loads
results.creator_credit: Kerry Regan, Max Pepper, Peter Dimond, South Australian Film Corporation and Pepper Audio Visual
results.brief_description:
This 1977 film demonstrates the importance of carrying a load safely on a truck. It details the necessary preparation for a drive, including the kind of load being carried, the stacking, placement and securing of the load. It includes a cameo appearance by American pro golfer Johnny Miller at the beginning, and a narrator speaking directly to the camera. Acknowledging that workers often find instructional videos condescending, the narrator speaks in a casual and familiar tone to appeal to the audience. He discusses the danger of petroleum and corrosive acids carried in tankers and the importance of stacking and securing a load correctly. The film ends with a dramatic re-enactment of experienced, yet careless, workers who secure a dangerous load onto a truck, which eventually explodes.

Produced for Mayne Nickless Limited by the South Australian Film Corporation and Pepper Audio Visual.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Cast: Johnny Miller, Roger Ward, Dave Taylor, Robyn Hamilton, Richard Pepper, Ian Gray, David Hursthouse

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Queensland Centenary Story, 1859-1959
results.creator_credit: Judy Campbell, Dulcie Holland, Eric Thompson, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: A brief account of the first hundred years of Queensland’s history, touching on its social life, its connection with two world wars, its industries and its agricultural and pastoral pursuits. Many sequences of historical intrest - in particular the visit of the Prince of Wales in 1921 and the Trans-Pacific flight by Sir Charles Kingsford Smith.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Judy Campbell, Dulcie Holland, Eric Thompson, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Queen cotton
results.creator_credit: C Beaumont, Cecil Musk and Merton Park
results.brief_description: Looks at the cotton industry in Lancashire which, in the middle of this century, supplied most of the world with cotton goods. Features cranes on the docks in Manchester unloading cotton from all over the world to supply the looms of Lancashire. Includes a fashion shows highlighting cotton fabrics used by well-known British designers. Photographed by Jimmy Rogers, music by William Alwyn and editing by C. Beaumont.

results.title: Pattern of life
results.creator_credit: Judy Campbell, Geoffrey Collings, Dahl Collings and Collings Productions
results.brief_description: Bark painting - inseparable from the social, cultural and religious life of the Australian Aborigine - shown as it is today to satisfy the demands of a commercial market and as it was, the changing pattern of the life of the Aborigine being reflected in his painting. Illustrations in Arnhem Land range from the fishing and hunting, musicians and dancing, to fighting, and mourning and burial ceremonies. In its western region we see various animal and plant totems in the attractive “x-ray” style, whilst elsewhere wind designs, clusters of stars, cycad and hybiscus trees are depicted.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Judy Campbell, Geoffrey Collings, Dahl Collings and Collings Productions
